body:
$!You need to tell the Child Benefit Office as soon as possible about any changes to your circumstances that could affect your Child Benefit - if you don't, your payments could be wrong.$!

##Changes to your circumstances

###Family changes

Tell the Child Benefit Office if:

- you marry, form a civil partnership or start living with a partner - and you're both getting Child Benefit
- you stop living with a partner and you’re both getting Child Benefit
- you have a baby
- another child comes to live with you
- you start getting paid by a local authority (or Health and Social Services Board or Trust in Northern Ireland) for a child you’re looking after

###Bank account, name or address changes

Tell the Child Benefit Office if:

- you want to change the account your Child Benefit is paid into
- you’ve changed your name or address

###Contributions to a child change or stop

Tell the Child Benefit Office if you:

- stop making contributions for a child who doesn’t live with you or is in hospital for more than 84 days
- go into hospital or prison for more than 8 weeks and you stop making contributions for your child

###Absence from the UK

Tell the Child Benefit Office if:

- you or your partner leave the UK permanently or for more than 52 weeks
- you leave the UK temporarily for more than 8 weeks, or more than 12 weeks because you or a member of your family is ill or has died
- you lose your right to reside in the UK
- your immigration status is changed by the Home Office

###Other changes

Tell the Child Benefit Office if:

- you or your partner start to pay social security contributions to, or get social security benefit from, a foreign country
- you leave Great Britain to go to Northern Ireland permanently, or Northern Ireland to go to Great Britain permanently

##Changes to your child's circumstances

###Your child's education or training

Tell the Child Benefit Office if your child:

- leaves school or college and starts paid work for 24 hours a week or more
- leaves school or college earlier than the date you told the Child Benefit Office
- stays on at school or college after the date you told the Child Benefit Office they would leave
- starts education that’s been provided by an employer or as part of any other job or role they have
- reduces the time they get supervised study at school or college to 12 hours a week or less
- starts a higher education course leading to a qualification like a degree
- starts being educated at home and is 16 or over
- starts training that’s provided by their employer
- starts a training course that’s not approved

###Your child's away from home

Tell the Child Benefit Office if your child:

- has lived away from you for more than 56 days in any 16-week period
- has been looked after by a local authority (or Health and Social Services Board or Trust in Northern Ireland), a voluntary organisation or held in secure or non-secure accommodation - for at least one day a week in the last 8 weeks
- leaves the UK permanently or for more than 52 weeks
- leaves the UK temporarily for more than 12 weeks
- leaves Great Britain to go to Northern Ireland permanently, or Northern Ireland to go to Great Britain permanently
- is in hospital or residential care for 12 weeks or more because they're ill or disabled and you won't be regularly spending money on them

##Other changes

Tell the Child Benefit Office if your child:

- changes their name
- starts getting benefits in their own right
- marries, forms a civil partnership or starts to live with a partner
- is held in legal custody for more than 8 weeks
- goes missing

##How to report changes

You can do this:

- [online](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/childbenefit/change-circs.htm "report a change of circumstances online")
- by calling or writing to the Child Benefit Office (details below)

$C

8am to 8pm, Monday to Friday

overview: Changes in your circumstances or your child's circumstances - what you need to report and how to report it
title: Report changes that affect your Child Benefit
